items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the lower River Churn as a result of recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue in the Cerney Wick area today, 7 October 2024. Further rain is expected today and tomorrow. Rainfall could be heavy in some places. River levels are expected to remain high along the river today.

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff will be out in the river catchment today checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 8 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is possible.

River levels are high on the lower River Cherwell following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 7 October 2024. Further rainfall is expected today and tomorrow. Rainfall could be heavy in some places. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days. River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 8 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high and steady on the River Windrush as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 7 October 2024, especially in the Bourton on the Water area. Further rainfall is expected today and tomorrow. Rainfall could be heavy in some places. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 8 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the River Evenlode and River Glyme following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 7 October 2024, especially in the Woodstock area. Further rainfall is expected today and tomorrow. Rainfall could be heavy in some places. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 8 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels remain high but have been lowering on the River Thames around Abingdon. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 7 October 2024. Further rain is expected today and tomorrow. Rainfall could be heavy in some places. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 8 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the Ginge Brook in response to recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, 7 October 2024. Further rainfall is expected today and tomorrow. Rainfall could be heavy in some places. River levels are expected to remain high over the next few days and sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 8 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is expected.

Flood warnings are in force for the River Ray at Islip and for the Murcott area. River levels are high but stable on the River Ray, however, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 7 October 2024. Further rainfall is expected today and tomorrow. Rainfall could be heavy in some places. River levels are currently stable but are expected to remain high over the next few days and will be sensitive to further rainfall. 

Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 8 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and its small tributaries from Calcutt to Lechlade

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Blunsdon Brook, Water Eaton Brook, Marston Meysey Brook, Share Ditch, Bydemill Brook, Westrop Brook, Downington Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the River Thames as a result of recent rainfall although they have been falling over the last few days. Flooding of low lying land and roads could possibly continue today, 7 October 2024, especially in the Kempsford area. Further rain is expected today and tomorrow. Rainfall could be heavy in some places. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall.

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 8 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high on the River Thame following recent rainfall. Flooding of property, low lying land, and roads is possible today, 7 October 2024. Further rainfall is expected today and tomorrow. Rainfall could be heavy in some places. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and will be sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 8 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River levels are rising steadily on the river Yeo at Sherborne Lake river gauge following Sunday’s rainfall.  Other rivers in the area could also respond to further rain forecast on Monday evening.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.  Flooding is possible from 6pm on 07/10/2024.
Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near the rivers.  
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and closely monitoring the situation.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 6 PM on 07/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are falling but remain responsive to further rainfall. This information is correct as of 07:00am on Monday 7 October. The causeway at Earith has approximately 10 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has 100 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney as approximately 110 centimetres of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We will update this message by 4pm today, Monday 7 October 2024.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are still high but continuing to fall steadily on the Lower River Colne and Frays River today, Sunday 6 October.
No property flooding is expected, but flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.
We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
The forecast rainfall is now expected overnight tonight, and into Monday 7 October. This could push river levels back up again.
This message will be updated by 6pm tomorrow, Monday 7 October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high on the River Dikler as a result of recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, 7 October 2024. Further rainfall is expected today and tomorrow. Rainfall could be heavy in some places. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff have been out checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 8 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the River Leach as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 7 October 2024, especially in the Lechlade area. Further rainfall is expected today and tomorrow. Rainfall could be heavy in some places. River levels are expected to remain high but slowly fall throughout today. River levels remain sensitive to rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 8 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 on 07/10/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End throughout today, Sunday 6 October 2024 and into tomorrow. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 on 07/10/2024, or before, if the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge following the recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days that may cause rivers to rise again. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 5pm on 07/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

We continue to monitor the situation.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels have fallen at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours We expect river levels to begin rising again later this morning. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 21:00 this evening, 07/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
River levels are still falling on the upper Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook. Flooding is still possible through Monday and into Tuesday. Property flooding is not expected.

Flooding may affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary. Drier conditions are expected from Monday to Tuesday and the situation should improve.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 12:00 Midday on 08/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Nene

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: The risk of flooding from the Middle Nene has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message: River levels are falling but remain high and are responsive to further rainfall. Based on the current forecast, flooding is still possible for the next few days. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. The forecast is for some heavier rainfall overnight tonight and a potential for continued heavy showers throughout the week, this week. Further rainfall will keep river levels high or could potentially see them rise again. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 5pm today, Monday 7 October 2024.

items.description: Middle River Great Ouse in Milton Keynes, Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is light showers tonight and heavier rainfall from Monday evening There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and reissue flood warnings and alerts when necessary.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but steady on the Chertsey Bourne following a period of sustained rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore expected today, 07/10/24, especially in the areas closest to the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey. Further rainfall is forecast in the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 08/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ivel in Hertfordshire and Central Bedfordshire
items.message: River levels have fallen along the Ivel. The forecast is for some heavier rainfall tonight, Monday 7 October 2024, and a potential for continued heavy showers throughout the week. Further rainfall could see river levels rise again. Based on the current forecast, we anticipate that we will reissue this flood alert proactively this evening. Continue to take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and will reissue flood warnings and alerts when necessary.

items.description: River Wreake in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: Ravensbourne area in the London Boroughs of Lewisham, Bromley, Greenwich and Croydon
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Bromley, Croydon, Greater London, Greenwich, Lewisham

items.message:
The flood alert for the river Ravensbourne remains in force. River levels are forecast to rise on the River Ravensbourne due to rainfall forecast overnight tonight Monday 07/10/2024 through to the early hours of tomorrow morning Tuesday 08/10/2024. Further rain showers are expected throughout the day on Tuesday with a further band of heavy rain forecast for Tuesday afternoon and overnight.  Flooding is forecast to affect low lying land near the River Ravensbourne between the hours of 11 pm tonight and throughout Tuesday the 8/10/2024. Property flooding is unlikely but remains possible. We are prepared to issue Flood Warnings if required. 

Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the river. 
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated by 5pm this afternoon 07/10/2024.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Central Bedfordshire, Beds Borough and Cambridgeshire from Wyboston to Brampton
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for some heavier rainfall tonight, Monday 7 October 2024, and a potential for continued heavy showers throughout the week. Further rainfall could see river levels rise again. Continue to take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and will reissue flood warnings and alerts when necessary.

items.description: River Ray for Islip
items.message:
Property flooding is possible.

River levels are high but slowly falling on the River Ray. Therefore flooding of properties, low lying land and roads is expected to continue this morning, 7 October 2024. Areas most at risk are properties closest to the river in Islip and surrounding villages. River levels are expected to remain steady today, but further rainfall is possible in the next few days, which may lead to increases in river levels. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water and do not drive along flooded roads. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 7 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low lying areas close to the River Great Ouse at Kempston
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is light showers tonight and heavier rainfall from Monday evening There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and reissue flood warnings and alerts when necessary.
